div.head: Reason for the Propositions
div.p: Friar Bartolomé de las Casas or Casaus, Bishop of Chiapa in New Spain, knew—by virtue fifty years of personal experience—the spiritual needs which the Spanish have caused in these Indies. Those who lived in this diocese were bound by these spiritual needs, and they once were among those most in need of correction for their errors and sins. Given Las Casas’ pastoral office, providing a remedy for their dangerous blindness was his concern. Such a remedy is usually given, after preaching and doctrine, only through confession. For this reason, Las Casas wrote a brief Confessional (Confesionario), in which he assigned certain rules to guide the conscience of confessors. Having brought this Confessional to Castilla, it was read, reread and examined, and approved and signed by six masters of theology.

But some who imitate the truth, ignorant of the true occurrences in the Indies, who would provide excuses for these most abominable happenings, wanted to defame the Confessional. They took issue with one of the rules in the Confessional, insisting that the Confessional would deny the kings of Castilla’s title and lordship over this world, since the Confessional affirms that everything the Spanish have done in the Indies is illegal, as a thing done without authority of a prince and against all natural justice. From this occasion the following propositions have their origin.
